entry.title: The Great Divide in Personality
entry.content:
Carl G. Jung, a Swiss psychiatrist who founded analytical psychology, distinguish the great divide between two personalities‚Äìextroverts and introverts‚Äìour society has been geared towards extroversion ideals. In the #Culture of Personality, we follow those who are confident and assertive than those who are reticent and unassuming 1. Researchers estimates 50-70% that make up the population are extroverts, whilst 16-50% were introverts. 2

Of course, personality has different flavors; its not always yin and yang of personality. If you take the The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) test, there are actually 16 types of personalities based on the theory of psychological types explained by Jung 3. The purpose of this test is to make the type theory accessible to individuals and groups, and to help individuals find their a suitable profession for their type.

Although MBTI is a paid service and is restricted for use only to certified professionals 4, there is a free online personality test similar to MBTI that is more accessible to anyone who desires to know their type 5.

entry.title: Culture of Character to Culture of Personality
entry.content:
In the Culture of Personality, people focus on how others perceived them and aspire to be bold and entertaining. ‚ÄúThe social role demanded of all in the new Culture of Personality was that of a performer,‚Äù Warren Sussman, influential cultural historian, famously wrote. ‚ÄúEvery American was to become a performing self.‚Äù As opposed to the Culture of Character where ‚Äúthe ideal self was serious, desciplined and honorable‚Äù. People value not so much as the impression they make in public but as how they behave in their privacy. The word personality weren‚Äôt even invented until the eighteenth century, and the idea of ‚Äúhaving a good personality‚Äù was not widespread until the twentieth. 1

A shift from the Culture of Character to the Culture of Personality brings new wave of cultural ideals# from which we would never quite recover.
